The week which passed so quietly and peaceably at the great house in Mansfield had a very different character at the Parsonage. To the young lady, at least, in each family, it brought very different feelings. What was tranquillity and comfort to Fanny was tediousness and vexation to Mary. Something arose from difference of disposition and habit: one so easily satisfied, the other so unused to endure; but still more might be imputed to difference of circumstances. She (Mary) was afraid she (Mary) had used some strong, some contemptuous expressions in speaking of the clergy, and that should not have been. It was ill-bred; it was wrong. Her (Mary) vexation did not end with the week. CHAPTER XXX

CHAPTER XXXI

Henry Crawford was at Mansfield Park again the next morning, and at an earlier hour than common visiting warrants. The two ladies were together in the breakfast-room, and, fortunately for him (Crawford), Lady Bertram was on the very point of quitting it as he (Crawford) entered. CHAPTER XXXVI

Edmund now believed himself perfectly acquainted with all that Fanny could tell, or could leave to be conjectured of her (Fanny) sentiments, and he (Edmund) was satisfied. It had been, as he (Edmund) before presumed, too hasty a measure on Crawford's side, and time must be given to make the idea first familiar, and then agreeable to her (Crawford). She (Crawford) must be used to the consideration of his (Edmund) being in love with her (Crawford), and then a return of affection might not be very distant.

He (Edmund) gave this opinion as the result of the conversation to his (Edmund) father; and recommended there being nothing more said to her (Crawford): no farther attempts to influence or persuade; but that everything should be left to Crawford's assiduities, and the natural workings of her (Crawford) own mind.

Sir Thomas promised that it should be so. Edmund's account of Fanny's disposition he (Edmund) could believe to be just; he (Edmund) supposed she (Fanny) had all those feelings, but he (Edmund) must consider it as very unfortunate that she (Fanny) _had_; for, less willing than his (Edmund) son to trust to the future, he (Edmund) could not help fearing that if such very long allowances of time and habit were necessary for her (Fanny), she (Fanny) might not have persuaded herself into receiving his (Edmund) addresses properly before the young man's inclination for paying them were over. There was nothing to be done, however, but to submit quietly and hope the best.

The promised visit from

``her (Crawford) friend,'' (Edmund/Mr. Bertram/Bertram)
as Edmund called Miss Crawford, was a formidable threat to Fanny, and she (Fanny) lived in continual terror of it. As a sister, so partial and so angry, and so little scrupulous of what she (Fanny) said, and in another light so triumphant and secure, she (Fanny) was in every way an object of painful alarm. Her (Fanny) displeasure, her (Fanny) penetration, and her (Fanny) happiness were all fearful to encounter; and the dependence of having others present when they met was Fanny's only support in looking forward to it. She (Fanny) absented herself as little as possible from Lady Bertram, kept away from the East room, and took no solitary walk in the shrubbery, in her (Bertram) caution to avoid any sudden attack.

She (Bertram) succeeded. She (Bertram) was safe in the breakfast-room, with her (Bertram) aunt, when Miss Crawford did come; and the first misery over, and Miss Crawford looking and speaking with much less particularity of expression than she (Crawford) had anticipated, Fanny began to hope there would be nothing worse to be endured than a half-hour of moderate agitation. ``I must speak to you for a few minutes somewhere'' (Fanny/Fanny Price)

They were no sooner in the hall than all restraint of countenance was over on Miss Crawford's side. ``Sad, sad girl! I do not know when I shall have done scolding you,'' (She)
and had discretion enough to reserve the rest till they might be secure of having four walls to themselves. ``Ha!'' (she)
she (Crawford) cried, with instant animation,
``am I here again? The East room! Once only was I in this room before'' (she)
; and after stopping to look about her (Crawford), and seemingly to retrace all that had then passed, she (Crawford) added,
``Once only before. Do you remember it? I came to rehearse. Your cousin came too; and we had a rehearsal. You were our audience and prompter. A delightful rehearsal. I shall never forget it. Here we were, just in this part of the room: here was your cousin, here was I, here were the chairs. Oh! why will such things ever pass away?'' (she)

Happily for her (Crawford) companion, she (Crawford) wanted no answer. Her (Crawford) mind was entirely self-engrossed. She (Crawford) was in a reverie of sweet remembrances.

``The scene we were rehearsing was so very remarkable! The subject of it so very--very--what shall I say? He (cousin) was to be describing and recommending matrimony to me. ``I have had a little fit since I came into this room, as you may perceive,'' (she)

``Good, gentle Fanny! when I think of this being the last time of seeing you for I do not know how long, I feel it quite impossible to do anything but love you.'' (Fanny/Fanny Price)

(the girls)

After this speech the two girls sat many minutes silent, each thoughtful: Fanny meditating on the different sorts of friendship in the world, Mary on something of less philosophic tendency. _She (Mary)_ first spoke again.

``How perfectly I remember my resolving to look for you upstairs, and setting off to find my way to the East room, without having an idea whereabouts it was! Another short fit of abstraction followed, when, shaking it off, she (Mary) thus attacked her (Mary) companion.

``Why, Fanny, you are absolutely in a reverie. Thinking, I hope, of one who is always thinking of you. For as to secrecy, Henry is quite the hero of an old romance, and glories in his (Henry) chains. You should come to London to know how to estimate your conquest. If you were to see how he (Henry) is courted, and how I am courted for his (Henry) sake! (Fanny/Fanny Price)

CHAPTER XXXVII

CHAPTER XXXVIII

The novelty of travelling, and the happiness of being with William, soon produced their natural effect on Fanny's spirits, when Mansfield Park was fairly left behind; and by the time their first stage was ended, and they were to quit Sir Thomas's carriage, she (Fanny) was able to take leave of the old coachman, and send back proper messages, with cheerful looks.

Of pleasant talk between the brother and sister there was no end. CHAPTER XLII

CHAPTER XLIII

CHAPTER XLIV

``My Dear Fanny,--Excuse me that I have not written before. Crawford told me that you were wishing to hear from me, but I found it impossible to write from London, and persuaded myself that you would understand my silence. Could I have sent a few happy lines, they should not have been wanting, but nothing of that nature was ever in my power. I am returned to Mansfield in a less assured state than when I left it. She (we) was in high spirits, and surrounded by those who were giving all the support of their own bad sense to her (we) too lively mind. I do not like Mrs. Fraser. Her (wife) ideas are not higher than her (wife) own fortune may warrant, but they are beyond what our incomes united could authorise. There is comfort, however, even here. ``I never will, no, I certainly never will wish for a letter again,'' (Fanny/Fanny Price)
was Fanny's secret declaration as she (Fanny) finished this.
``What do they bring but disappointment and sorrow? Not till after Easter! How shall I bear it? And my poor aunt talking of me every hour!'' (Fanny/Fanny Price)

Such sensations, however, were too near akin to resentment to be long guiding Fanny's soliloquies. She (Fanny) was soon more softened and sorrowful. His (Edmund) warm regard, his (Edmund) kind expressions, his (Edmund) confidential treatment, touched her (Fanny) strongly. He (Edmund) was only too good to everybody. Everybody at all addicted to letter-writing, without having much to say, which will include a large proportion of the female world at least, must feel with Lady Bertram that she (Bertram) was out of luck in having such a capital piece of Mansfield news as the certainty of the Grants going to Bath, occur at a time when she (Bertram) could make no advantage of it, and will admit that it must have been very mortifying to her (Bertram) to see it fall to the share of her (Bertram) thankless son, and treated as concisely as possible at the end of a long letter, instead of having it to spread over the largest part of a page of her (Bertram) own. There was a rich amends, however, preparing for her (Grant). Lady Bertram's hour of good luck came. Within a few days from the receipt of Edmund's letter, Fanny had one from her (Fanny) aunt, beginning thus--

``My Dear Fanny,--I take up my pen to communicate some very alarming intelligence, which I make no doubt will give you much concern'' (aunt)
.

This was a great deal better than to have to take up the pen to acquaint her (Fanny) with all the particulars of the Grants' intended journey, for the present intelligence was of a nature to promise occupation for the pen for many days to come, being no less than the dangerous illness of her (Fanny) eldest son, of which they had received notice by express a few hours before.

Tom had gone from London with a party of young men to Newmarket, where a neglected fall and a good deal of drinking had brought on a fever; and when the party broke up, being unable to move, had been left by himself at the house of one of these young men to the comforts of sickness and solitude, and the attendance only of servants. Instead of being soon well enough to follow his (Tom) friends, as he (Tom) had then hoped, his (Tom) disorder increased considerably, and it was not long before he (Tom) thought so ill of himself as to be as ready as his (Tom) physician to have a letter despatched to Mansfield.

``This distressing intelligence, as you may suppose,'' (ladyship)
observed her (Tom) ladyship, after giving the substance of it,
``has agitated us exceedingly, and we cannot prevent ourselves from being greatly alarmed and apprehensive for the poor invalid, whose state Sir Thomas fears may be very critical; and Edmund kindly proposes attending his (Edmund) brother immediately, but I am happy to add that Sir Thomas will not leave me on this distressing occasion, as it would be too trying for me. Fanny's feelings on the occasion were indeed considerably more warm and genuine than her (Tom) aunt's style of writing. She (Tom) felt truly for them all. She (Tom) could just find selfishness enough to wonder whether Edmund _had_ written to Miss Crawford before this summons came, but no sentiment dwelt long with her (Crawford) that was not purely affectionate and disinterestedly anxious. Her (Crawford) aunt did not neglect her (Crawford): she (Crawford) wrote again and again; they were receiving frequent accounts from Edmund, and these accounts were as regularly transmitted to Fanny, in the same diffuse style, and the same medley of trusts, hopes, and fears, all following and producing each other at haphazard. ``He (sufferer) is just come, my dear Fanny, and is taken upstairs; and I am so shocked to see him (sufferer), that I do not know what to do. I am sure he (sufferer) has been very ill. Poor Tom! The real solicitude now awakened in the maternal bosom was not soon over. Susan was her (Susan) only companion and listener on this, as on more common occasions. Susan was always ready to hear and to sympathise. Nobody else could be interested in so remote an evil as illness in a family above an hundred miles off; not even Mrs. Price, beyond a brief question or two, if she (Price) saw her (Price) daughter with a letter in her (Price) hand, and now and then the quiet observation of,

``My poor sister Bertram must be in a great deal of trouble.'' (daughter)

So long divided and so differently situated, the ties of blood were little more than nothing. An attachment, originally as tranquil as their tempers, was now become a mere name. Mrs. Price did quite as much for Lady Bertram as Lady Bertram would have done for Mrs. Price. Three or four Prices might have been swept away, any or all except Fanny and William, and Lady Bertram would have thought little about it; or perhaps might have caught from Mrs. Norris's lips the cant of its being a very happy thing and a great blessing to their poor dear sister Price to have them so well provided for.

CHAPTER XLV

At about the week's end from his (William) return to Mansfield, Tom's immediate danger was over, and he (William) was so far pronounced safe as to make his (William) mother perfectly easy; for being now used to the sight of him (William) in his (William) suffering, helpless state, and hearing only the best, and never thinking beyond what she (mother) heard, with no disposition for alarm and no aptitude at a hint, Lady Bertram was the happiest subject in the world for a little medical imposition. They judged it best that Lady Bertram should not be harassed by alarms which, it was to be hoped, would prove unfounded; but there was no reason why Fanny should not know the truth. The family were not consumptive, and she (Fanny) was more inclined to hope than fear for her (Fanny) cousin, except when she (Fanny) thought of Miss Crawford; but Miss Crawford gave her (Crawford) the idea of being the child of good luck, and to her (Crawford) selfishness and vanity it would be good luck to have Edmund the only son.

Even in the sick chamber the fortunate Mary was not forgotten. Edmund's letter had this postscript.

``On the subject of my last, I had actually begun a letter when called away by Tom's illness, but I have now changed my mind, and fear to trust the influence of friends. When Tom is better, I shall go.'' (unknown)

Such was the state of Mansfield, and so it continued, with scarcely any change, till Easter. A line occasionally added by Edmund to his (Edmund) mother's letter was enough for Fanny's information. Tom's amendment was alarmingly slow.

Easter came particularly late this year, as Fanny had most sorrowfully considered, on first learning that she (Fanny) had no chance of leaving Portsmouth till after it. It came, and she (Fanny) had yet heard nothing of her (Fanny) return--nothing even of the going to London, which was to precede her (Fanny) return. Her (Fanny) aunt often expressed a wish for her (Fanny), but there was no notice, no message from the uncle on whom all depended. She (Fanny) supposed he (uncle) could not yet leave his (uncle) son, but it was a cruel, a terrible delay to her (Fanny). The end of April was coming on; it would soon be almost three months, instead of two, that she (Fanny) had been absent from them all, and that her (Fanny) days had been passing in a state of penance, which she (Fanny) loved them too well to hope they would thoroughly understand; and who could yet say when there might be leisure to think of or fetch her (Fanny)?

Her (Fanny) eagerness, her (Fanny) impatience, her (Fanny) longings to be with them, were such as to bring a line or two of Cowper's Tirocinium for ever before her (Fanny).

``With what intense desire she (sister) wants her (sister) home,'' (she)
was continually on her (Fanny) tongue, as the truest description of a yearning which she (Fanny) could not suppose any schoolboy's bosom to feel more keenly.

``When I go back into Northamptonshire, or when I return to Mansfield, I shall do so and so.'' (she)

Could she (Fanny) have been at home, she (Fanny) might have been of service to every creature in the house. She (Fanny) felt that she (Fanny) must have been of use to all. ``Forgive me, my dear Fanny, as soon as you can, for my long silence, and behave as if you could forgive me directly. This is my modest request and expectation, for you are so good, that I depend upon being treated better than I deserve, and I write now to beg an immediate answer. One should be a brute not to feel for the distress they are in; and from what I hear, poor Mr. Bertram has a bad chance of ultimate recovery. I thought little of his (Bertram) illness at first. I looked upon him (Bertram) as the sort of person to be made a fuss with, and to make a fuss himself in any trifling disorder, and was chiefly concerned for those who had to nurse him (Bertram); but now it is confidently asserted that he (Bertram) is really in a decline, that the symptoms are most alarming, and that part of the family, at least, are aware of it. I need not say how rejoiced I shall be to hear there has been any mistake, but the report is so prevalent that I confess I cannot help trembling. To have such a fine young man cut off in the flower of his (man) days is most melancholy. Poor Sir Thomas will feel it dreadfully. I really am quite agitated on the subject. Fanny, Fanny, I see you smile and look cunning, but, upon my honour, I never bribed a physician in my life. Poor young man! If he (man) is to die, there will be _two_ poor young men less in the world; and with a fearless face and bold voice would I say to any one, that wealth and consequence could fall into no hands more deserving of them. CHAPTER XLVIII

Let other pens dwell on guilt and misery. I quit such odious subjects as soon as I can, impatient to restore everybody, not greatly in fault themselves, to tolerable comfort, and to have done with all the rest.

My Fanny, indeed, at this very time, I have the satisfaction of knowing, must have been happy in spite of everything. She (Fanny) must have been a happy creature in spite of all that she (Fanny) felt, or thought she (Fanny) felt, for the distress of those around her (Fanny). She (Fanny) had sources of delight that must force their way. She (Fanny) was returned to Mansfield Park, she (Fanny) was useful, she (Fanny) was beloved; she (Fanny) was safe from Mr. Crawford; and when Sir Thomas came back she (Fanny) had every proof that could be given in his (Thomas) then melancholy state of spirits, of his (Thomas) perfect approbation and increased regard; and happy as all this must make her (Fanny), she (Fanny) would still have been happy without any of it, for Edmund was no longer the dupe of Miss Crawford.

It is true that Edmund was very far from happy himself. He (Edmund) was suffering from disappointment and regret, grieving over what was, and wishing for what could never be. She (Crawford) knew it was so, and was sorry; but it was with a sorrow so founded on satisfaction, so tending to ease, and so much in harmony with every dearest sensation, that there are few who might not have been glad to exchange their greatest gaiety for it.

Sir Thomas, poor Sir Thomas, a parent, and conscious of errors in his (Thomas) own conduct as a parent, was the longest to suffer. He (Thomas) felt that he (Thomas) ought not to have allowed the marriage; that his (Thomas) daughter's sentiments had been sufficiently known to him (Thomas) to render him (Thomas) culpable in authorising it; that in so doing he (Thomas) had sacrificed the right to the expedient, and been governed by motives of selfishness and worldly wisdom. These were reflections that required some time to soften; but time will do almost everything; and though little comfort arose on Mrs. Rushworth's side for the misery she (Rushworth) had occasioned, comfort was to be found greater than he (Thomas) had supposed in his (Thomas) other children. Julia's match became a less desperate business than he (Thomas) had considered it at first. She (Julia) was humble, and wishing to be forgiven; and Mr. Yates, desirous of being really received into the family, was disposed to look up to him (Yates) and be guided. He (Yates) was not very solid; but there was a hope of his (Yates) becoming less trifling, of his (Yates) being at least tolerably domestic and quiet; and at any rate, there was comfort in finding his (Yates) estate rather more, and his (Yates) debts much less, than he (Yates) had feared, and in being consulted and treated as the friend best worth attending to. There was comfort also in Tom, who gradually regained his (Tom) health, without regaining the thoughtlessness and selfishness of his (Tom) previous habits. He (Tom) was the better for ever for his (Tom) illness. He (Tom) had suffered, and he (Tom) had learned to think: two advantages that he (Tom) had never known before; and the self-reproach arising from the deplorable event in Wimpole Street, to which he (Tom) felt himself accessory by all the dangerous intimacy of his (Tom) unjustifiable theatre, made an impression on his (Tom) mind which, at the age of six-and-twenty, with no want of sense or good companions, was durable in its happy effects. He (Tom) became what he (Tom) ought to be: useful to his (Tom) father, steady and quiet, and not living merely for himself.

Here was comfort indeed! and quite as soon as Sir Thomas could place dependence on such sources of good, Edmund was contributing to his (Edmund) father's ease by improvement in the only point in which he (Edmund) had given him (Edmund) pain before--improvement in his (Edmund) spirits. After wandering about and sitting under trees with Fanny all the summer evenings, he (Edmund) had so well talked his (Edmund) mind into submission as to be very tolerably cheerful again.

These were the circumstances and the hopes which gradually brought their alleviation to Sir Thomas, deadening his (Thomas) sense of what was lost, and in part reconciling him (Thomas) to himself; though the anguish arising from the conviction of his (Thomas) own errors in the education of his (Thomas) daughters was never to be entirely done away.

Too late he (Thomas) became aware how unfavourable to the character of any young people must be the totally opposite treatment which Maria and Julia had been always experiencing at home, where the excessive indulgence and flattery of their aunt had been continually contrasted with his (Thomas) own severity. He (Thomas) saw how ill he (Thomas) had judged, in expecting to counteract what was wrong in Mrs. Norris by its reverse in himself; clearly saw that he (Thomas) had but increased the evil by teaching them to repress their spirits in his (Thomas) presence so as to make their real disposition unknown to him (Thomas), and sending them for all their indulgences to a person who had been able to attach them only by the blindness of her (Norris) affection, and the excess of her (Norris) praise.

Here had been grievous mismanagement; but, bad as it was, he (Thomas) gradually grew to feel that it had not been the most direful mistake in his (Thomas) plan of education. Something must have been wanting _within_, or time would have worn away much of its ill effect. He (Thomas) feared that principle, active principle, had been wanting; that they had never been properly taught to govern their inclinations and tempers by that sense of duty which can alone suffice. They had been instructed theoretically in their religion, but never required to bring it into daily practice. To be distinguished for elegance and accomplishments, the authorised object of their youth, could have had no useful influence that way, no moral effect on the mind. He (Thomas) had meant them to be good, but his (Thomas) cares had been directed to the understanding and manners, not the disposition; and of the necessity of self-denial and humility, he (Thomas) feared they had never heard from any lips that could profit them.

Bitterly did he (Thomas) deplore a deficiency which now he (Thomas) could scarcely comprehend to have been possible. Wretchedly did he (Thomas) feel, that with all the cost and care of an anxious and expensive education, he (Thomas) had brought up his (Thomas) daughters without their understanding their first duties, or his (Thomas) being acquainted with their character and temper.

The high spirit and strong passions of Mrs. Rushworth, especially, were made known to him (Thomas) only in their sad result. She (Rushworth) was not to be prevailed on to leave Mr. Crawford. She (Rushworth) hoped to marry him (Crawford), and they continued together till she (Rushworth) was obliged to be convinced that such hope was vain, and till the disappointment and wretchedness arising from the conviction rendered her (Rushworth) temper so bad, and her (Rushworth) feelings for him (Crawford) so like hatred, as to make them for a while each other's punishment, and then induce a voluntary separation.

She (Rushworth) had lived with him (Crawford) to be reproached as the ruin of all his (Crawford) happiness in Fanny, and carried away no better consolation in leaving him (Crawford) than that she (Fanny) _had_ divided them. What can exceed the misery of such a mind in such a situation?

Mr. Rushworth had no difficulty in procuring a divorce; and so ended a marriage contracted under such circumstances as to make any better end the effect of good luck not to be reckoned on. She (Fanny) had despised him (Rushworth), and loved another; and he (Rushworth) had been very much aware that it was so. The indignities of stupidity, and the disappointments of selfish passion, can excite little pity. His (Rushworth) punishment followed his (Rushworth) conduct, as did a deeper punishment the deeper guilt of his (Rushworth) wife. _He (Rushworth)_ was released from the engagement to be mortified and unhappy, till some other pretty girl could attract him (Rushworth) into matrimony again, and he (Rushworth) might set forward on a second, and, it is to be hoped, more prosperous trial of the state: if duped, to be duped at least with good humour and good luck; while she (girl) must withdraw with infinitely stronger feelings to a retirement and reproach which could allow no second spring of hope or character.

Where she (girl) could be placed became a subject of most melancholy and momentous consultation. Mrs. Norris, whose attachment seemed to augment with the demerits of her (Norris) niece, would have had her (Norris) received at home and countenanced by them all. Sir Thomas would not hear of it; and Mrs. Norris's anger against Fanny was so much the greater, from considering _her (Fanny)_ residence there as the motive. She (Fanny) persisted in placing his (Thomas) scruples to _her (Fanny)_ account, though Sir Thomas very solemnly assured her (Fanny) that, had there been no young woman in question, had there been no young person of either sex belonging to him (Thomas), to be endangered by the society or hurt by the character of Mrs. Rushworth, he (character) would never have offered so great an insult to the neighbourhood as to expect it to notice her (Rushworth). As a daughter, he (character) hoped a penitent one, she (Rushworth) should be protected by him (character), and secured in every comfort, and supported by every encouragement to do right, which their relative situations admitted; but farther than _that_ he (character) could not go. Maria had destroyed her (Maria) own character, and he (character) would not, by a vain attempt to restore what never could be restored, by affording his (character) sanction to vice, or in seeking to lessen its disgrace, be anywise accessory to introducing such misery in another man's family as he (man) had known himself.

It ended in Mrs. Norris's resolving to quit Mansfield and devote herself to her (Norris) unfortunate Maria, and in an establishment being formed for them in another country, remote and private, where, shut up together with little society, on one side no affection, on the other no judgment, it may be reasonably supposed that their tempers became their mutual punishment.

Mrs. Norris's removal from Mansfield was the great supplementary comfort of Sir Thomas's life. His (Thomas) opinion of her (Norris) had been sinking from the day of his (Thomas) return from Antigua: in every transaction together from that period, in their daily intercourse, in business, or in chat, she (Norris) had been regularly losing ground in his (Thomas) esteem, and convincing him (Thomas) that either time had done her (Norris) much disservice, or that he (Thomas) had considerably over-rated her (Norris) sense, and wonderfully borne with her (Norris) manners before. He (Thomas) had felt her (Norris) as an hourly evil, which was so much the worse, as there seemed no chance of its ceasing but with life; she (Norris) seemed a part of himself that must be borne for ever. To be relieved from her (Norris), therefore, was so great a felicity that, had she (Norris) not left bitter remembrances behind her (Norris), there might have been danger of his (Thomas) learning almost to approve the evil which produced such a good.

She (Norris) was regretted by no one at Mansfield. She (Norris) had never been able to attach even those she (Norris) loved best; and since Mrs. Rushworth's elopement, her (Rushworth) temper had been in a state of such irritation as to make her (Rushworth) everywhere tormenting. Not even Fanny had tears for aunt Norris, not even when she (Rushworth) was gone for ever.

That Julia escaped better than Maria was owing, in some measure, to a favourable difference of disposition and circumstance, but in a greater to her (Maria) having been less the darling of that very aunt, less flattered and less spoilt. Her (Maria) beauty and acquirements had held but a second place. She (Maria) had been always used to think herself a little inferior to Maria. Her (Maria) temper was naturally the easiest of the two; her (Maria) feelings, though quick, were more controllable, and education had not given her (Maria) so very hurtful a degree of self-consequence.

She (Maria) had submitted the best to the disappointment in Henry Crawford. After the first bitterness of the conviction of being slighted was over, she (Maria) had been tolerably soon in a fair way of not thinking of him (Crawford) again; and when the acquaintance was renewed in town, and Mr. Rushworth's house became Crawford's object, she (Crawford) had had the merit of withdrawing herself from it, and of chusing that time to pay a visit to her (Crawford) other friends, in order to secure herself from being again too much attracted. This had been her (Crawford) motive in going to her (Crawford) cousin's. Mr. Yates's convenience had had nothing to do with it. She (Crawford) had been allowing his (Yates) attentions some time, but with very little idea of ever accepting him (Yates); and had not her (Crawford) sister's conduct burst forth as it did, and her (Crawford) increased dread of her (Crawford) father and of home, on that event, imagining its certain consequence to herself would be greater severity and restraint, made her (Crawford) hastily resolve on avoiding such immediate horrors at all risks, it is probable that Mr. Yates would never have succeeded. She (Crawford) had not eloped with any worse feelings than those of selfish alarm. It had appeared to her (Crawford) the only thing to be done. Maria's guilt had induced Julia's folly.

Henry Crawford, ruined by early independence and bad domestic example, indulged in the freaks of a cold-blooded vanity a little too long. Once it had, by an opening undesigned and unmerited, led him (Crawford) into the way of happiness. Could he (Crawford) have been satisfied with the conquest of one amiable woman's affections, could he (Crawford) have found sufficient exultation in overcoming the reluctance, in working himself into the esteem and tenderness of Fanny Price, there would have been every probability of success and felicity for him (Crawford). His (Crawford) affection had already done something. Her (Price) influence over him (Crawford) had already given him (Crawford) some influence over her (Price). Would he (Crawford) have deserved more, there can be no doubt that more would have been obtained, especially when that marriage had taken place, which would have given him (Crawford) the assistance of her (Price) conscience in subduing her (Price) first inclination, and brought them very often together. Would he (Crawford) have persevered, and uprightly, Fanny must have been his (Crawford) reward, and a reward very voluntarily bestowed, within a reasonable period from Edmund's marrying Mary.

Had he (Edmund) done as he (Edmund) intended, and as he (Edmund) knew he (Edmund) ought, by going down to Everingham after his (Everingham) return from Portsmouth, he (Everingham) might have been deciding his (Everingham) own happy destiny. But he (Everingham) was pressed to stay for Mrs. Fraser's party; his (Everingham) staying was made of flattering consequence, and he (Everingham) was to meet Mrs. Rushworth there. Curiosity and vanity were both engaged, and the temptation of immediate pleasure was too strong for a mind unused to make any sacrifice to right: he (Everingham) resolved to defer his (Everingham) Norfolk journey, resolved that writing should answer the purpose of it, or that its purpose was unimportant, and staid. He (Everingham) saw Mrs. Rushworth, was received by her (Rushworth) with a coldness which ought to have been repulsive, and have established apparent indifference between them for ever; but he (Everingham) was mortified, he (Everingham) could not bear to be thrown off by the woman whose smiles had been so wholly at his (Everingham) command: he (Everingham) must exert himself to subdue so proud a display of resentment; it was anger on Fanny's account; he (Everingham) must get the better of it, and make Mrs. Rushworth Maria Bertram again in her (Maria) treatment of himself.

In this spirit he (Everingham) began the attack, and by animated perseverance had soon re-established the sort of familiar intercourse, of gallantry, of flirtation, which bounded his (Everingham) views; but in triumphing over the discretion which, though beginning in anger, might have saved them both, he (Everingham) had put himself in the power of feelings on her (Maria) side more strong than he (Everingham) had supposed. She (Maria) loved him (Everingham); there was no withdrawing attentions avowedly dear to her (Maria). He (Everingham) was entangled by his (Everingham) own vanity, with as little excuse of love as possible, and without the smallest inconstancy of mind towards her (Maria) cousin. To keep Fanny and the Bertrams from a knowledge of what was passing became his (cousin) first object. Secrecy could not have been more desirable for Mrs. Rushworth's credit than he (cousin) felt it for his (cousin) own. When he (cousin) returned from Richmond, he (cousin) would have been glad to see Mrs. Rushworth no more. All that followed was the result of her (Rushworth) imprudence; and he (cousin) went off with her (Rushworth) at last, because he (cousin) could not help it, regretting Fanny even at the moment, but regretting her (Fanny) infinitely more when all the bustle of the intrigue was over, and a very few months had taught him (cousin), by the force of contrast, to place a yet higher value on the sweetness of her (Fanny) temper, the purity of her (Fanny) mind, and the excellence of her (Fanny) principles.

That punishment, the public punishment of disgrace, should in a just measure attend _his (cousin)_ share of the offence is, we know, not one of the barriers which society gives to virtue. In this world the penalty is less equal than could be wished; but without presuming to look forward to a juster appointment hereafter, we may fairly consider a man of sense, like Henry Crawford, to be providing for himself no small portion of vexation and regret: vexation that must rise sometimes to self-reproach, and regret to wretchedness, in having so requited hospitality, so injured family peace, so forfeited his (Crawford) best, most estimable, and endeared acquaintance, and so lost the woman whom he (Crawford) had rationally as well as passionately loved.

After what had passed to wound and alienate the two families, the continuance of the Bertrams and Grants in such close neighbourhood would have been most distressing; but the absence of the latter, for some months purposely lengthened, ended very fortunately in the necessity, or at least the practicability, of a permanent removal. Dr. Grant, through an interest on which he (Grant) had almost ceased to form hopes, succeeded to a stall in Westminster, which, as affording an occasion for leaving Mansfield, an excuse for residence in London, and an increase of income to answer the expenses of the change, was highly acceptable to those who went and those who staid.

Mrs. Grant, with a temper to love and be loved, must have gone with some regret from the scenes and people she (Grant) had been used to; but the same happiness of disposition must in any place, and any society, secure her (Grant) a great deal to enjoy, and she (Grant) had again a home to offer Mary; and Mary had had enough of her (Mary) own friends, enough of vanity, ambition, love, and disappointment in the course of the last half-year, to be in need of the true kindness of her (Mary) sister's heart, and the rational tranquillity of her (Mary) ways. They lived together; and when Dr. Grant had brought on apoplexy and death, by three great institutionary dinners in one week, they still lived together; for Mary, though perfectly resolved against ever attaching herself to a younger brother again, was long in finding among the dashing representatives, or idle heir-apparents, who were at the command of her (Mary) beauty, and her (Mary) #20,000, any one who could satisfy the better taste she (Mary) had acquired at Mansfield, whose character and manners could authorise a hope of the domestic happiness she (Mary) had there learned to estimate, or put Edmund Bertram sufficiently out of her (Mary) head.

Edmund had greatly the advantage of her (Mary) in this respect. He (Edmund) had not to wait and wish with vacant affections for an object worthy to succeed her (Mary) in them. Scarcely had he (Edmund) done regretting Mary Crawford, and observing to Fanny how impossible it was that he (Edmund) should ever meet with such another woman, before it began to strike him (Edmund) whether a very different kind of woman might not do just as well, or a great deal better: whether Fanny herself were not growing as dear, as important to him (Edmund) in all her (Fanny) smiles and all her (Fanny) ways, as Mary Crawford had ever been; and whether it might not be a possible, an hopeful undertaking to persuade her (Crawford) that her (Crawford) warm and sisterly regard for him (Edmund) would be foundation enough for wedded love.

I purposely abstain from dates on this occasion, that every one may be at liberty to fix their own, aware that the cure of unconquerable passions, and the transfer of unchanging attachments, must vary much as to time in different people. I only entreat everybody to believe that exactly at the time when it was quite natural that it should be so, and not a week earlier, Edmund did cease to care about Miss Crawford, and became as anxious to marry Fanny as Fanny herself could desire.

With such a regard for her (Fanny), indeed, as his (Edmund) had long been, a regard founded on the most endearing claims of innocence and helplessness, and completed by every recommendation of growing worth, what could be more natural than the change? Loving, guiding, protecting her (Fanny), as he (Edmund) had been doing ever since her (Fanny) being ten years old, her (Fanny) mind in so great a degree formed by his (Edmund) care, and her (Fanny) comfort depending on his (Edmund) kindness, an object to him (Edmund) of such close and peculiar interest, dearer by all his (Edmund) own importance with her (Fanny) than any one else at Mansfield, what was there now to add, but that he (Edmund) should learn to prefer soft light eyes to sparkling dark ones. And being always with her (Fanny), and always talking confidentially, and his (Edmund) feelings exactly in that favourable state which a recent disappointment gives, those soft light eyes could not be very long in obtaining the pre-eminence.

Having once set out, and felt that he (Edmund) had done so on this road to happiness, there was nothing on the side of prudence to stop him (Edmund) or make his (Edmund) progress slow; no doubts of her (Fanny) deserving, no fears of opposition of taste, no need of drawing new hopes of happiness from dissimilarity of temper. Her (Fanny) mind, disposition, opinions, and habits wanted no half-concealment, no self-deception on the present, no reliance on future improvement. Even in the midst of his (Edmund) late infatuation, he (Edmund) had acknowledged Fanny's mental superiority. What must be his (Edmund) sense of it now, therefore? She (Fanny) was of course only too good for him (Edmund); but as nobody minds having what is too good for them, he (Edmund) was very steadily earnest in the pursuit of the blessing, and it was not possible that encouragement from her (Fanny) should be long wanting. Timid, anxious, doubting as she (Fanny) was, it was still impossible that such tenderness as hers should not, at times, hold out the strongest hope of success, though it remained for a later period to tell him (Edmund) the whole delightful and astonishing truth. His (Edmund) happiness in knowing himself to have been so long the beloved of such a heart, must have been great enough to warrant any strength of language in which he (Edmund) could clothe it to her (Fanny) or to himself; it must have been a delightful happiness. But there was happiness elsewhere which no description can reach. Let no one presume to give the feelings of a young woman on receiving the assurance of that affection of which she (woman) has scarcely allowed herself to entertain a hope.

Their own inclinations ascertained, there were no difficulties behind, no drawback of poverty or parent. It was a match which Sir Thomas's wishes had even forestalled. Sick of ambitious and mercenary connexions, prizing more and more the sterling good of principle and temper, and chiefly anxious to bind by the strongest securities all that remained to him (Thomas) of domestic felicity, he (Thomas) had pondered with genuine satisfaction on the more than possibility of the two young friends finding their natural consolation in each other for all that had occurred of disappointment to either; and the joyful consent which met Edmund's application, the high sense of having realised a great acquisition in the promise of Fanny for a daughter, formed just such a contrast with his (Edmund) early opinion on the subject when the poor little girl's coming had been first agitated, as time is for ever producing between the plans and decisions of mortals, for their own instruction, and their neighbours' entertainment.

Fanny was indeed the daughter that he (Edmund) wanted. His (Edmund) charitable kindness had been rearing a prime comfort for himself. His (Edmund) liberality had a rich repayment, and the general goodness of his (Edmund) intentions by her (Fanny) deserved it. He (Edmund) might have made her (Fanny) childhood happier; but it had been an error of judgment only which had given him (Edmund) the appearance of harshness, and deprived him (Edmund) of her (Fanny) early love; and now, on really knowing each other, their mutual attachment became very strong. After settling her (Fanny) at Thornton Lacey with every kind attention to her (Fanny) comfort, the object of almost every day was to see her (Fanny) there, or to get her (Fanny) away from it.

Selfishly dear as she (Fanny) had long been to Lady Bertram, she (Bertram) could not be parted with willingly by _her (Bertram)_. No happiness of son or niece could make her (Bertram) wish the marriage. But it was possible to part with her (Bertram), because Susan remained to supply her (Susan) place. Susan became the stationary niece, delighted to be so; and equally well adapted for it by a readiness of mind, and an inclination for usefulness, as Fanny had been by sweetness of temper, and strong feelings of gratitude. Susan could never be spared. First as a comfort to Fanny, then as an auxiliary, and last as her (Fanny) substitute, she (Fanny) was established at Mansfield, with every appearance of equal permanency. Her (Fanny) more fearless disposition and happier nerves made everything easy to her (Fanny) there. With quickness in understanding the tempers of those she (Fanny) had to deal with, and no natural timidity to restrain any consequent wishes, she (Fanny) was soon welcome and useful to all; and after Fanny's removal succeeded so naturally to her (Fanny) influence over the hourly comfort of her (Fanny) aunt, as gradually to become, perhaps, the most beloved of the two. In _her (Fanny)_ usefulness, in Fanny's excellence, in William's continued good conduct and rising fame, and in the general well-doing and success of the other members of the family, all assisting to advance each other, and doing credit to his (William) countenance and aid, Sir Thomas saw repeated, and for ever repeated, reason to rejoice in what he (Thomas) had done for them all, and acknowledge the advantages of early hardship and discipline, and the consciousness of being born to struggle and endure.

With so much true merit and true love, and no want of fortune and friends, the happiness of the married cousins must appear as secure as earthly happiness can be. Equally formed for domestic life, and attached to country pleasures, their home was the home of affection and comfort; and to complete the picture of good, the acquisition of Mansfield living, by the death of Dr. Grant, occurred just after they had been married long enough to begin to want an increase of income, and feel their distance from the paternal abode an inconvenience.

On that event they removed to Mansfield; and the Parsonage there, which, under each of its two former owners, Fanny had never been able to approach but with some painful sensation of restraint or alarm, soon grew as dear to her (Fanny) heart, and as thoroughly perfect in her (Fanny) eyes, as everything else within the view and patronage of Mansfield Park had long been.
